DOC.HEAD: Lebanon Complains to U.N. About Israeli Attacks
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon said today it was lodging an urgent complaint with the U.N. Security Council about Israel's latest ground and air attacks that reportedly killed 12 people and wounded 31. The attacks, which occurred 12 hours apart on Tuesday, destroyed two guerrilla bases of the Communist Party in central and southern Lebanon. Prime Minister Salim Hoss' office said instructions were being transmitted to Lebanon's U.N. mission to complain of ``this blatant aggression.'' The office said Lebanon would not ask for a council debate. Israeli paratroopers backed by tanks and helicopter gunships destroyed one guerrilla base in southeast Lebanon before dawn, and warplanes blasted a command post of the same group at sunset further to the north. Rescuers worked under spotlights overnight to dig out victims from the rubble of the two-story command post in the coastal town of Rmeile, 20 miles south of Beirut. Police said the final casualty toll of the Rmeile attack stood at 10 killed and 28 wounded, the heaviest among Israel's 18 air raids into Lebanon this year. Twenty-eight people have been killed and 137 wounded in the 18 air strikes since Jan. 11. Two Communist guerrillas were killed and three wounded in the earlier ground assault on the base in the southeastern village of Nabi Safi. The assault, staged by 100 paratroopers backed by four tanks and eight armored personnel carriers, was the Israeli army's heaviest ground advance into Lebanon since an assault on the Syrian-backed Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command on Dec. 9, 1988. The attack force advanced from Israel's self-proclaimed border zone, a two- to 15-mile wide buffer zone north of the Israeli border, which Israel and the Israeli-allied South Lebanese Army have controlled since 1982. The Communists have been blamed for several terrorist attacks in Israel as well as the attempted assassination in November 1988 of the South Lebanese Army commander. Elsewhere in southern Lebanon, rival Shiite Moslem militias battled into a fifth day today in southern Lebanon. Police said eight people were killed and 37 wounded in artillery and tank fire duels Tuesday and early today between the fundamentalist Hezbollah and the Syrian-backed Amal militia. That raised the overall toll to 46 killed and 187 wounded since the current round of fighting began Saturday. The two factions have been vying for mastery of Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the country's largest sect, for more than two years. The overall toll of the intermittent power struggle since May 1987 stands at 617 killed and 1,766 wounded.
